description.narrative: Papua New Guniea REDD+ Readiness Project - Forest Carbon Platform Facility (FCPF) second phase

activity-description.narrative: The World Banks FCPF REDD+ Readiness II project building on earlier REDD+ readiness efforts under UN-REDD National Programme and continuation under phase one of FCPFs REDD+ Readiness initiative.
The World Banks FCPF REDD+ Readiness II project building on earlier REDD+ readiness efforts under UN-REDD National Programme and continuation under phase one of FCPFs REDD+ Readiness initiative.
The World Banks FCPF REDD+ Readiness II project building on earlier REDD+ readiness efforts under UN-REDD National Programme and continuation under phase one of FCPFs REDD+ Readiness initiative.

description.narrative: * Level of multi-agency National REDD+ Steering Committee, including subnational level committees * Extent of participation of stakeholders in REDD+ readiness activities at national levels * Extent to which capacity of stakeholders, including non-government stakeholders improved * Extent to which national communication tools on REDD+ developed * Extent to which province specific communication tools on REDD+ developed * Extent to which awareness of national stakeholders on REDD+ increased * Extent to which subnational stakeholders, local communities and IPs, are aware about REDD+ * Extent to which national consultation and participation mechanisms developed and institutionalised * Extent to which gender concerns are integrated into the proposed measures by the NRFIP, other policies and SIS * Extent of progress in National REDD+ Strategy and National REDD+ Finance and Investment Plan (NRFIP) * Extent of progress in policy support on Protected Areas (CEPA) * Extent of progress in review of Climate Change (Review of Climate Change (Management) Act) * Extent of progress in review of Forestry Act * Extent of progress in review of Agricultural Policy * Extent of progress in review of Sustainable Land Use Policy * Extent of progress in establishment of Palm Oil Platform in the country * Extent of progress in development of Safeguards Information System including Grievance Redress Mechanism (GRM) * Extent of progress in REDD+ finance mechanisms * Extent to which sub-national consultation and participation mechanisms developed and institutionalised * Extent to which sub-national governments can assess key causes of D&D and propose coordinated management approaches to address these causes * Extent to which a landscape and integrated approach is promoted for REDD+ * Extent of progress in developing Stakeholders’ Engagement Plans in Madang, East New Britain and West New Britain * Extent to which gender sensitive stakeholder engagement tools, comment.narrative: * Multi-agency National REDD+ Steering Committee, including subnational level committees function partially * Stakeholders engaged in planning (measured by the number of participants for the TWCs and sub-working groups’ meetings aggregated by sex) * Regular number of stakeholders participated in REDD+ capacity building events * Communication strategy drafted/PNG REDD+ website, Facebook and twitter available * Province specific communication tools on REDD+ drafted * Communication and knowledge products developed * Communities and Indigenous People in sample sites demonstrate a limited understanding of REDD+ * Moderate participation of national stakeholders in REDD+ consultation process * Relevant policy documents refer to their possible impacts on men and women * No initial assessment and analysis on progress in National REDD+ Strategy and National REDD+ Finance and Investment Plan (NRFIP) * No initial draft manuals on the progress in policy support on Protected Areas (CEPA) * No initial draft manuals on the progress in policy support on CCMA (CCDA) * No initial draft manuals on the progress in policy support on Forestry Act (PNGFA) * No initial draft manuals on the progress in policy support on Agriculture (DAL) * No initial draft manuals on the progress in policy support on Sustainable Land Use Policy (DLPP) * No initial draft manuals on the progress in policy support on Palm Oil Platform * Initial assessment and analysis on the development of Safeguards Information System including Grievance Redress Mechanism (GRM) * Initial assessment and analysis on REDD+ finance mechanisms * Moderate participation of subnational stakeholders in REDD+ consultation process * Initial assessments of causes of D&D and propose coordinated management approaches to address these causes * No management plans at the landscape level * Absence of stakeholder engagement tools: communication and participation tools including FPIC and gender tools in pilot provinces * Relevant policy documen

* The FCPF Project continued support of the legislative reviews such as the review of Climate Change (Management) Act (CCMA), review of the National Sustainable Land Use Policy, review of PNG’s Forestry Act. They were aimed to align the land use legislative frameworks (climate change, forestry, land use) with the National REDD+ Strategy. Regional stakeholder consultations on the review of CCMA with participation of more than 300 representatives (28% female) from the national, provincial and district administrations, civil society, private sector and landowner groups were carried out in four regions of PNG. As a result of expansive consultations, draft recommendations to incorporate into the CCMA were developed and circulated with stakeholders. * The FCPF Project recently supported the first regional workshop in Mt. Hagen for the highlands region stakeholders to review of the National Sustainable Land Use Policy. This consultation was held on the 2 – 5 December 2019, which brought more than 40 representatives (40% female) from the national agencies, provincial administration and landowners from the Highlands region. * Assessments of potential options for benefit sharing and financial management for REDD+ have been delivered. These present a potential framework for development of a REDD+ financial management mechanism and benefit distribution system in PNG. The work draws on international best practice as well as current benefit sharing structures in PNG. Due to complexity and political nature of many of the decisions within these proposals further work is needed to fully develop an approach that has CCDA and broader government and civil society ownership. * The FCPF Project is collaborating with the UNDP’s Green Commodities Programme (GCP) to support the GoPNG strengthen its approach to palm oil development. Central to this approach is the establishment of the PNG Multi-stakeholder Palm Oil Platform (PNG POP). The FCPF project through high level consultations has continued provision of the support to the Department of Agriculture and Livestock (DAL) to develop a policy submission on establishment of the PNGPOP, kick start the development of National Palm Oil Policy and PNG’s Declaration on Sustainable Palm Oil. However due to changes in government and gaps in high level support the process has yet to gain an NEC decision that would provide the platform with a strong mandate for action. * Engagement plans for East New Britain, West New Britain and Madang Provinces were finalised in 2019. They were aimed to support the implementation of PNG’s National REDD+ Strategy with the full and effective participation of key stakeholders. Given that REDD+ implementation is at a very early stage of development (with the Safeguard Information System not yet in place, and the REDD+ operational model undefined) the immediate goal of this stakeholder engagement program was to develop a capacity to improve stakeholder coordination. Through the capacity development trainings, a customised provincial stakeholder engagement plans were developed. More than 800 stakeholders (40% female) attended provincial consultations and capacity building programmes. To support these engagement plans, a success story “Ensuring Women Have a Say - Putting Gender at the Heart of Free, Prior and Informed Consent” was featured in the UNDP Asia Pacific Gender Equality Dispatch. * To improve the efficiency of forestry planning, the FCPF Project supported PNG Forest Authority to review National Guidelines on developing Provincial Forestry Plans. This support has also included trialling the development of specific Provincial Forestry Plans in three target provinces of East New Britain, West New Britain and Madang. The National Forest Plan Guideline is developed based on lessons learned from this exercise and will scaled up across all provinces of the country.

*National REDD+ Steering Committee established and functional * Communications and knowledge management products developed * Better understanding of TWG members on REDD+ as a result of trainings and practical sessions (series of REDD+ Expert Trainings) * The National Sustainable Land Use Policy developed * The Statement of Intent on Sustainable Palm Oil developed; PNG Palm Oil Platform established and functional * The review of climate change, agriculture and forest legislation initiated in participatory manner * The review of National Forest Plan initiated * National Guidelines on GRM developed and endorsed by the Government * Social and Environmental Screening Procedure and Environmental and Social Management Plan for the NRFIP and Risk and Benefits Management Framework developed * Stakeholder engagement plans developed in three pilot provinces and implementation initiated * Provincial Forest Plans in Madang, ENB and WNB reviewed and submitted to PEC for endorsement * Sustainable Development Plans of Madang, WNB and ENB reviewed and new plans submitted to PEC for approval * Capacity of provincial stakeholders enhanced through capacity building trainings and awareness raising activities * FPIC Guideline finalised and approved by the government * Approved FRL for PNG * Strengthened web-portal and NFMS * NFI process supported.

The National Executive Council (NEC) approved the creation of PNG’s National REDD+ Steering Committee (NRSC) (NEC Decision 126. May 2017). This will be a high-level, cross-sectoral coordination and decision-making body for REDD+. Chaired by CCDA, it will be supported at a technical level by Technical Working Committees on NRS, Safeguards and NFMS/FREL which were effective during NRS development and are mandated by the CCMA. This however requires further support to strengthen REDD+ coordination mechanism aligned with the climate policies in the country.
The REDD+ Communications and Knowledge Management Strategy was developed and endorsed by CCDA following extensive consultation with all stakeholders representing public and private sector as well as civil society organisations. The main goal is to support the REDD+ readiness process to further enhance communication and knowledge of all relevant stakeholders on REDD+ within PNG’s context. It involves scaling-up awareness raising and image building, promotes and enhances communications and knowledge management, and capacity building among all relevant stakeholder groups. To strengthen REDD+ branding, a logo was developed and endorsed by all stakeholders while a REDD+ website is under development to help stakeholders access information on REDD+ and developments in the country.
A number of key communications products (the list of articles and publications is attached in Annex 1) were also produced and disseminated. These included news articles , press releases , social media contents, posters and a 2019-year calendar. The project has also reproduced 3,000 copies of REDD+ policy briefs and were distributed at strategic events such as REDD+ expert trainings, high level meetings targeting key policy and decision makers. Copies have also been made available for key sector agencies to share with key stakeholders within their network. The project has also produced 500 copies of the NRS and delivered to key government, private and civil society officials. Copies of these publications have also been made available on the online platforms for wider accessibility.
The REDD+ Expert trainings with participation of over 800 (up to 40% female) representatives from the relevant agencies and sectors to discuss the RFIP was carried out by the project. To demonstrate a national ownership, all these consultations were led by the CCDA as the lead national agency for coordination of climate change related activities in the country.
International Consultant hired by the project to provide technical support to the Government of PNG to review its National Sustainable Land Use Policy (NSLUP). A national secretariat was established comprising of senior technical experts from the Department of Lands and Physical Planning (DLPP) and the review of NSLUP has been initiated.
The Project has established strong partnership with UNDP’s Green Commodities Programme to continue support on the establishment of PNG’s Palm Oil Platform and development of national policy on sustainable palm oil. This initiative is aimed to address one of the main drivers of deforestation of Commercial Agriculture driven by unsustainable Palm Oil in PNG . For this reason and to kick-off the work of the platform, UNDP PNG Country Office recruited a National Coordinator and a Technical Specialist.
The project contracted service providers to review the Climate Change (Management) Act (2015) and Forestry Act . A number of initial consultations were carried out with respective government sector agencies. These activities will be continued in 2019.
The main reason for delay in the achievement of this target is to review the Forestry Act by the PNG Forest Authority. The project has initiated the review and it is anticipated to kick off the National Forest Plan review after the sectoral legislation revision.
A Grievance Redress Mechanism (GRM) for the NRS was developed based on earlier findings from the GRM scoping study. Finalised in August 2018, the GRM guidelines outlined the scope and supporting elements of a GRM, proposed an institutional structure, identified and differentiated steps for national-level and subnational-level GRMs.
A social and environmental screening was undertaken by UNDP as part of the project inception process, and a medium risk rating was assigned. In compliance with the Common Approach, UNDP, as the delivery partner, has been applying its Social and Environmental Standards (SES) to the project in adherence to environmental and social safeguards. The Safeguards TWC is comprised of representatives from different government departments, civil society organizations and private sectors was established. The objective of the TWC is to meet the need for PNG to respond to the multiple international safeguard requirements, in particular, those under the UNFCCC (Cancun safeguards) and the FCPF [Strategic Environmental and Social Assessment (SESA) and Environmental and Social Management Framework (ESMF)], through the adoption of a Country Approach to Safeguards (CAS).
The project selected target provinces of East New Britain and West New Britain as well as Madang and one of the examples is the development of provincial stakeholder engagement plans and tools that are customized to province-specific social and cultural constructs, norms and practices. More than 800 people (48% female) participated in undertaking the stakeholder’s engagement plans development process. The outcome of the assessment demonstrates that the provincial administrations are likely to be the single most important group for facilitating information exchange around REDD+ within the provinces. These plans and operational tools for gender inclusion and Free, Prior and Informed Consent will be finalised in 2019 .
In close partnership with the PNG Forestry Authority reviewed PNG’s Provincial Forest Guidelines (PFP) to improve forest governance and logging operations which are a major issue in the country. The Provincial Forest Plans will be piloted in three provinces of Madang, East and West New Britain and upon successful integration, will be scaled up throughout other 19 provinces of PNG.
The project in partnership with UNDP GEF initiated procurement process to select a potential service provider to develop Sustainable Development Plans, however, after numerous re-advertisements, no suitable companies were identified by the project. This action will be implemented in 2019.
Within the framework of the assignment on the development of stakeholder engagement plans in pilot provinces, 6 Provincial Capacity building trainings and awareness raising activities were successfully carried out in three pilot provinces of East and West New Britain and Madang provinces.
Capacity development tools, including developing operational tools for gender and Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC) are under development and expected to be finalised in 2019
The Project signed UN Agency to UN Agency Agreement with FAO to implement Outcome 4 of the FCPF Project. FAO will continue to support PNGFA and CCDA to prepare and report its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) and the further development and operation of PNG’s NFMS as PNG moves towards piloting of REDD+ activities. The PNG’s Forest Reference Level (FRL) was developed and endorsed by the Government and successfully submitted to UNFCCC. signed UN Agency to UN Agency Agreement with FAO to implement Outcome 4 of the FCPF Project. FAO will continue to support PNGFA and CCDA to prepare and report its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) and the further development and operation of PNG’s NFMS as PNG moves towards piloting of REDD+ activities. REDD+ results in 2014 and 2015 against the REDD+ FRL was estimated and the report was produced as REDD+ Technical Annex of PNG’s first Biennial Update report (BUR) in 2018, expected to be submitted to UNFCCC in April 2019 .
Field assessment of National Forest Inventory (NFI) was conducted at 19 clusters with 72 plots in three provinces: 13 in Madang, 2 in Eastern Highlands, and 4 in West New Britain in 2018 in collaboration with an EU-funded project. Forest biomass data, which is essential for estimating Emission Factor, and biodiversity data, which is crucial for improving the national safeguards framework and information system were presented at NFI Research Conference held in February 2018. Conference proceedings containing 21 research papers was published .
